learning.supervised.methods.knn

Class NHBNN

  • java.lang.Object
    • learning.supervised.Classifier
      • learning.supervised.methods.knn.NHBNN
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Citable, NSFUserInterface, java.io.Serializable, ValidateableInterface, AutomaticKFinderInterface, DistMatrixUserInterface, DistToPointsQueryUserInterface, NeighborPointsQueryUserInterface

    public class NHBNN
extends Classifier
implements AutomaticKFinderInterface, DistMatrixUserInterface, NSFUserInterface, DistToPointsQueryUserInterface, NeighborPointsQueryUserInterface, java.io.Serializable
    This class implements the Naive Hubness-Bayesian k-nearest neighbor algorithm that was proposed in the following paper: A Probabilistic Approach to Nearest-Neighbor Classification: Naive Hubness Bayesian kNN by Nenad Tomasev, Milos Radovanovic, Dunja Mladenic and Mirjana Ivanovic, presented at the Conference on Information and Knowledge Management (CIKM) in 2011 in Glasgow. It is a Naive Bayesian interpretation of the k-nearest neighbor rule. Each neighbor occurrence is interpreted as an event, as a new defining feature for the query instance. Unlike in standard Naive Bayes, though - some of these 'features', or rather feature values never occur on the training data and are observed on the test data. This happens for points that are orphans in the kNN graph on the training data and points like this arise frequently in high-dimensional data due to the hubness phenomenon. Even for non-orphan anti-hub points, deriving proper probability conditionals is difficult. On the other hand, most neighbor occurrences in high-dimensional data are hub occurrences and for those points it is possible to derive good class-conditional occurrence probabilities and occurrence-conditional class affiliation probabilities as well. In any case, it is possible to apply the modified Naive Bayes rule for classification based on the kNN set. This approach has later been shown to be quite promising in class-imbalanced high-dimensional data. It was also a basis for development of ANHBNN that was later presented at ECML/PKDD 2013 in Prague.
    See Also:

      • setDistMatrix

        public void setDistMatrix(float[][] distMatrix)
        Description copied from interface: DistMatrixUserInterface
        Distance matrix setter.
        Specified by:
        setDistMatrix in interface DistMatrixUserInterface
        Parameters:
        distMatrix - float[][] representing the upper triangular distance matrix. Each row i contains only entries for j > i, due to distances being symmetric. For compression, the zeroed lower triangular entries are not stored, so each row i contains (size - i - 1) elements. The entry in distMatrix[i][j] corresponds to the distance between data points i and i + j + 1.

      • getDistMatrix

        public float[][] getDistMatrix()
        Description copied from interface: DistMatrixUserInterface
        Distance matrix getter.
        Specified by:
        getDistMatrix in interface DistMatrixUserInterface
        Returns:
        float[][] representing the upper triangular distance matrix. Each row i contains only entries for j > i, due to distances being symmetric. For compression, the zeroed lower triangular entries are not stored, so each row i contains (size - i - 1) elements. The entry in distMatrix[i][j] corresponds to the distance between data points i and i + j + 1.
